questions.text: A 50- year male presented with complaints of right leg pain for 2 months and an ulcer over the left foot for 1 month. He is a known smoker for the past 25 years and a known diabetic on oral hypoglycaemic drugs. On examination of limb ulcer of size, 2*2cm is seen over the dorsal aspect of the left foot. Skin is thinned, with diminished growth of hair. Peripheral pulses are feeble. Which of the following is the most common cause of limb ischemia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atherosclerosis Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of limb ischemia. Causes of Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Disease Common Causes Atherosclerosis (MC) Buerger's disease Takayasu arteritis SLE Post-traumatic Radiation injury Less common causes External compression Popliteal entrapment Thoracic outlet syndrome Retroperitoneal fibrosis Coarctation of aorta Cystic medial necrosis Fibromuscular dysplasia

Highyeild:

Acute Limb Ischaemia :- ALI is an emergency that requires rapid, accurate clinical assessment and emergency surgical treatment. ALI typically occurs as a result of embolic arterial occlusion or trauma, but less common causes, including thrombosed popliteal artery aneurysm and popliteal artery entrapment, should be kept in mind during patient assessment Clinical Features :- Five P’s : Pain, Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis, and Pulselessness The skin is initially cold and pale , but as time progresses it slowly becomes mottled; first, non-fixed (blanching to pressure) and then fixed (non-blanching), indicating skin death. Neurological function deteriorates with time, progressing from paraesthesia to eventual complete loss of sensory and motor function, causing an insensate and paralyzed limb (a poor prognostic sign). Muscle groups are weakened and painful; manual compression of affected muscle groups may cause pain owing to ischemia-induced injury – rhabdomyolysis Pulses are absent distally but the femoral pulse may be palpable , even thrusting, as distal occlusion results in forceful expansion of the artery with each pressure wave despite the lack of flow Investigations : ECG Creatinine Kinase RFT Imaging - DUS or CTA Treatment : Immediate Administration - 5000U of heparin IV Embolectomy Thrombolysis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- : Option: B. It predominantly affects young male smokers in their 30s, it Involve involves small and medium-sized vessels (Tibial, plantar and radial arteries) causing distal limb ischemia and localized digital gangrene. Option: C. Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by recurrent episodic vasospasm of the digits precipitated by a stimulus such as environmental cold or emotional stress, manifesting as tricolor changes- white, blue, and red. Option: D. Vasculitis refers to a primary inflammatory process involving blood vessels with resultant transmural injury, necrosis, and obstruction or obliteration of the lumen. Vessels of any size or location can be affected.

Extraedge:

Clinicians reviewing a patient with sudden onset leg pain should have a high index of suspicion for ALI. Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and results in limb loss. IHD is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in resource-rich countries.

questions.text: A 60 -year- old complains of claudication of both limbs for 1 month, pain starts with 1st step of the walk itself and pain increases with a downhill walk, and decreases with an uphill walk. What type of claudication pain is it?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neurological Neurogenic claudication occurs due to lumbar cord stenosis. The spine extends in the downhill walk with the narrowing of the spinal canal and pain increases. When symptoms mimicking the symptoms of intermittent vascular claudication arise from lumbar canal stenosis, the condition is termed neurogenic pseudo-claudication. Pseudo-claudication refers to a variety of conditions that may mimic vascular intermittent claudication. The condition that is most commonly confused with vascular intermittent claudication is neurological pseudo-claudication due to lumbar canal stenosis Common in both males and females (no predisposition) Pain reduces on flexed posture/ position Pain Increases on Walking downhill and Decreases on Downhill Walk

Highyeild:

Claudication : Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the muscles that are: brought on by walking; not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis); relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes). The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day. It is decreased, first, by increasing the work demands and hence oxygen requirements of the muscles affected, e.g. walking uphill, increasing the speed of walking and/or carrying heavy weights, and, second, by general health conditions that reduce the oxygen delivery capacity of the arterial system, e.g. anemia or cardiorespiratory disease. The muscle group affected by claudication is classically one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease and is usually felt in the posterior calf as the superficial femoral artery is the most commonly affected artery (70% of cases). Aortoiliac disease (30% of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication Leriche’s syndrome is buttock claudication combined with sexual impotence, which is secondary to arterial insufficiency

Extraedge:

Only one-quarter of patients presenting with intermittent claudication will experience symptomatic deterioration during their lifetime and the overall risk of progression to CLTI and amputation is small, with <5% of patients requiring amputation over a 5-year period.

Segmental inflammatory disease, affecting small and medium-sized arteries in the upper and lower extremities. It is an inflammatory process that involves neighboring veins and nerves also. questions.text: A middle- aged male presented with claudication pain. CT angiography revealed occlusion of superficial femoral artery. He has been planned for femoro-popliteal bypass. Which is the best graft for femoro-popliteal bypass:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Saphenous vein Choice of Conduit for Infra-inguinal Bypass grafting:- The autogenous vein is superior to prosthetic conduits for all infra-inguinal bypasses, even in the above-knee position. This preference is applicable not only for the initial bypass but also for re-operative cases. For long bypasses, the ipsilateral great saphenous vein, contralateral great saphenous vein, small saphenous vein, arm vein, and spliced vein are used in decreasing order of preference. If only a short segment of vein is missing, the SFA can be endarterectomized and the proximal anastomosis performed distally to decrease the length of the conduit and to avoid harvesting and splicing additional vein. When the great saphenous vein is not available and a relatively short bypass is necessary, the arm vein or small saphenous vein is effective. The small saphenous vein is of particular utility when a posterior approach is used. If a longer bypass with vein is necessary, the arm vein is preferable because it is less awkward to harvest. Another conduit alternative is to harvest the upper arm basilic, median cubital, and cephalic veins in continuity, while incising valves in the basilic segment and using the cephalic segment in reversed configuration to provide a relatively long, unspliced autogenous conduit.

questions.text: A 30 -year -old lady had episodes of her fingers becoming white and incapable of fine movements. Then it resolves slowly and becomes red after a period of cyanosis. The episodes are more frequent in winter. Which of the following is the Most common precipitation of the above disease is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exposure to cold There is abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold (more frequent episodes in the winter) These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movement.

Highyeild:

Raynaud’s disease : This idiopathic condition usually occurs in young women and affects the hands more than the feet. There is abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements. The capillaries then dilate and fill with slowly flowing deoxygenated blood, resulting in the digits becoming swollen and dusky. As the attack passes off, the arterioles relax, oxygenated blood returns to the dilated capillaries and the digits become red. Thus, the condition is recognized by the characteristic sequence of blanching, dusky cyanosis, and red engorgement, often accompanied by pain. Superficial necrosis is very uncommon. This condition must be distinguished from Raynaud’s syndrome, which has similar features and is the term most often used for a Peripheral arterial manifestation of collagen disease. Treatment : Raynaud’s disease consists of protection from colds and avoidance of pulp and nail bed infections. Calcium antagonists, such as nifedipine, may also have a role to play and electrically heated gloves can be useful in winter. Sympathectomy has been used in the past but it is either ineffective or its effects are short-lived.

Extraedge:

Raynaud’s Syndrome has clinical features same as Raynaud’s disease but they may be much more aggressive. Acrocyanosis may be confused with Raynaud’s disease but it is painless and not episodic.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding abdominal aortic aneurysm:

options.label: A
options.text: MC rupture is posterolateral into retroperitoneum

options.label: B
options.text: Posterior rupture comes alive to hospital with retroperitoneal hematoma in most cases

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Abdominal aortic aneurysms can rupture anteriorly into the peritoneal cavity (20%) or posterolaterally into the retroperitoneal space (80%) Posterior rupture on the other hand produces a retroperitoneal hematoma. Often a brief period ensues when a combination of moderate hypotension and the resistance of the retroperitoneal tissues arrests further hemorrhage and may allow transport to hospital CT scanning should be used to establish the diagnosis and to confirm a rupture and whether an EVAR is possible

Investigations : CT Scan Management : Early diagnosis (abdominal/back pain, pulsatile mass, shock) Immediate resuscitation (oxygen, intravenous replacement therapy, central line) Maintain systolic pressure, but not >100 mmHg Urinary catheter Cross-match blood Rapid transfer to the operating room Treatment: Endovascular Repair Symptomatic AAA: These patients most commonly present with abdominal and/ or back pain but the aneurysm is not ruptured on CT scan. Pain may also occur in the thigh and groin because of nerve compression. Gastrointestinal, urinary, and venous symptoms can also be caused by pressure from an abdominal aneurysm Treatment: Surgery done as soon as possible Postoperative Complications: Cardiac (ischemia and infarction) and respiratory (atelectasis and lower lobe consolidation) complications are more common after open repair Endoleak, graft migration, metal strut fracture , and graft limb occlusion are more common after EVAR. Type of endoleak Definition Type I Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to an ineffective seal at the proximal (la) or distal (lb) end of the stent-graft Type II Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to retrograde flow of blood from aortic collaterals, e.g. IMA, lumbar arteries Type III Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to structural failure of the stent-graft as a result of component disconnection (Illa) or stent fabric tear (Illb Type IV Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to stent-graft fabric porosity Type V (endotension) Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac without evidence of types I-IV endoleak

Most abdominal aortic aneurysms remain asymptomatic until rupture occurs; the risk of rupture increases with increasing size (diameter) of the aneurysm. A UK national screening program for abdominal aortic aneurysms commenced in 2009 offering an ultrasonography scan to men in their 65th year. Solution:

Debakey type I and type II Type A of Stanford corresponds to Debakey Type 1 & 2

Highyeild:

There are two classifications of Aortic dissection, both of which are limited in their application but widely used. The DeBakey classification is based on the pattern of dissection, whereas the Stanford classification is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved. DeBakey classification: Type 1 : Intimal tear in ascending aorta, involving descending aorta Type 2 : Dissection limited to ascending aorta Type 3 : Intimal tear descending aorta with distal propagation of the dissection. Stanford classification: Type A : Dissection involves ascending aorta (proximal dissection) Type B: Limited to the descending aorta (distal dissection). Stanford classification of aortic dissections according to whether the ascending aorta is involved (type A) or not (type B). This is simpler than the DeBakey classification (types I, II and III).

questions.text: Most common site of Peripheral aneurysm:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Popliteal artery Popliteal artery aneurysm accounts for 70% of all peripheral aneurysms classically diagnosed in males in their seventh decade of life; 50% are bilateral. Examination of the abdominal aorta is indicated if a popliteal aneurysm is found because one-third are accompanied by aortic dilatation. Popliteal aneurysms present as swelling behind the knee or with symptoms caused by complications, such as severe ischemia following thrombosis or distal ischemia as a result of emboli. Diagnosis: Usually confirmed with duplex scanning but the assessment of the distal vessels (with CT, MR, or DSA) is important prior to repair if the foot pulses are diminished or absent. Treatment: Exclusion Bypass and Inlay Repair An asymptomatic aneurysm exceeding 20mm in diameter should be considered for elective repair, to prevent future complications. Some surgeons would also offer elective repair for smaller diameters if the sac contains a thrombus, because of a perceived increased risk of distal embolisation. All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms, including those in which single crural vessel embolization has occurred, should be considered for repair.

questions.text: Seldinger needle is used for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arteriography The most popular access needle is the Seldinger needle, which can be used for single- and double-wall puncture techniques in arterial wall puncture.

Highyeild:

Needles are used to achieve percutaneous vascular access. The size of the needle will be dictated by the diameter of the guide wire used. Most often, an 18-gauge needle is used, as it will accept a 0.035-inch guidewire. A 21-gauge micropuncture needle will accept a 0.018- inch guidewire. The most popular access needle is the Seldinger needle, which can be used for single- and double-wall puncture techniques. Femoral arterial puncture is the most common site for access. The common femoral artery (CFA) is punctured over the medial third of the femoral head, which is landmarked using fluoroscopy. The single-wall puncture technique requires a sharp, bevelled needle tip and no central stylet. The anterior wall of the vessel is punctured with the bevel of the needle pointing up, and pulsatile back-bleeding indicates an intraluminal position. This method is most useful for graft punctures, patients with abnormal clotting profiles, or if thrombolytic therapy is anticipated. Once the needle assumes an intraluminal position, verified by pulsatile back-bleeding, the guidewire may be advanced. This is always passed gently and under fluoroscopic guidance to avoid subintimal dissection or plaque disruption. Double-wall puncture techniques are performed with a blunt needle that has a removable inner cannula. The introducer needle punctures both walls of the artery and is withdrawn until bleeding is obtained to confirm intraluminal position prior to advancing a guidewire. There can be troublesome bleeding from the posterior arterial wall puncture; therefore, single puncture techniques are preferred. Retrograde femoral access is the most common arterial access technique.

questions.text: True about Carotid body tumour is/are:

options.label: A
options.text: Incidence is high in people living at high altitudes

questions.correct_answer: A. Incidence is high in people living at high altitudes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incidence is high in people living at high altitudes This rare tumour has a higher incidence in areas where people live at high altitudes because of chronic hypoxia leading to carotid body hyperplasia.

Highyeild:

Carotid Body Tumour : This is a rare tumour that has a higher incidence in areas where people live at high altitudes because of chronic hypoxia leading to carotid body hyperplasia. The tumours most commonly present in the fifth decade. Approximately 10% of patients have a family history, with familial cases caused by mutations in the genes for the succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) enzyme. Clinical Features: Long history of a slowly enlarging, painless lump at the carotid bifurcation Pharyngeal mass that pushes the tonsil medially and anteriorly The mass is firm, rubbery, pulsatile, mobile from side to side but not up and down and can sometimes be emptied by firm pressure, after which it slowly refills in a pulsatile manner. A bruit may also be present Investigation: Carotid Angiogram MRI Contraindication (Biopsy and Fine needle aspiration) Treatment: Type I tumours are localized and do not involve more than 180° of the carotid vessels; Type II tumours surround the vessel by over 180°, and type III tumours completely encase the vessels and are more challenging to resect with higher complications and a possible need for vessel reconstruction.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:-: Option: B. The tumours arise from the chemoreceptor cells on the medial side of the carotid bulb and, at this point, the tumour is adherent to the carotid wall. The cells of the chemodectoma are not hormonally active and the tumours are usually benign with only a small number of cases producing proven metastases. Option: C. Because these tumours rarely metastasise and their overall rate of growth is slow, the need for surgical removal must be considered carefully as complications of surgery are potentially serious. The operation is best avoided in elderly patients. Radiotherapy has no effect.

Extraedge:

Because these tumours rarely metastasise and their overall rate of growth is slow, the need for surgical removal must be considered carefully as complications of surgery are potentially serious. The operation is best avoided in elderly patients. Radiotherapy will not cure the tumour but can prevent further growth.
